name: Memoria
description: Two stories, two main characters, one epic experience: in Memoria, players travel through different time periods, while following two distinct protagonists: Sadja, a southern princess who wants to be a war hero, and Geron, a bird catcher who wants to lift a curse from his girlfriend.

reviews.review_text: If you are playing this before have played The Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav, you are making an HUGE mistake. Stop, play Chains of Satinav, which is absolutely great and them return to Memoria.  You will love this even more, I guarantee.  Awesome game.

“As the stone over the scarab, so rules the scarab over the stone” –  The riddle from the Ancient Vault    After finishing Memoria’s prequel   „The Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav”    I was anxiously waiting for this game, wanting to know how exactly would Geron’s and Nuri’s tale end. Sitting to the game I had some expectations about the overall course of it, and involved mechanics. I was somewhat uneasy about announced introduction of another main character –  Princess Sadja , but overall I did not expected any drastic changes between “Memoria” and its predecessor.  To my surprise however, after just a couple of minutes I had to completely abandon all these previous assumptions, and for the benefit of the game that is ! Not only all the strong points of “Chains of Satinav” were still present – with its stunning music, beautifully hand-painted backgrounds and complete, detailed voice-over, but also, to my content “Memoria” introduced a handful of new ideas making the game even better !  In ‘Memoria’, contrary to the previous game, we follow two seemingly separate stories. One starts right after the events of the previous game, which left Nuri, a former fairy and Geron’s girlfriend, turned into a Raven, and the featuring Princess Sadja, a heroine from over 450 years ago, whose footsteps we’ll have to follow. The narrative is written perfectly, telling us the truly moving story, full of surprising events, magic and sacrifice. The characters are likeable, interesting, and their motivations are truly believable.  The main flaw of “TDE: Chains of Satinav’s” gameplay were its puzzles, which although solid and logical, turned out to be quite simple, and after a while may have felt a bit repetitive. In “Memoria” this problem is nonexistent, ‘cause almost each of game’s many brilliant puzzles feels unique. All that thanks to an improved  magic mechanic , greatly augmented in comparison to “Chains of Satinav”, with both spells variety increasing, and their impact on puzzle solving changing dramatically. Now we are allowed to choose from much larger diversity of powers than before, each coming with a distinct applications.  Summing up, I have to admit that “Memoria” has left me speechless, and after finishing it,  I won’t hesitate saying that this jewel should be counted among best adventure games of the last decade.  Both plotline and the puzzle design in this game are as close to perfection as I’d dare to ask, and above that we are once again pleased with astonishing aesthetics known from the previous game in the series.  I’d strongly recommend this game not only to those who enjoy this particular genere, but also to anyone who has even the slightest liking to a top grade fantasy tales !   Pros:  - Deep and intriguing plotline with two entangled keynotes. - Huge amount of witty puzzles. - Unique magic mechanics. - Beautiful soundtrack perfectly fitting the story ! - Sequel to   “Chains of Satinav”   - Set in a vast fantasy setting of ‘Dark Eye’   Cons:  - Boxed “Collectors Edition” available only in Germany

A note first. This game is the sequel to Chains of Satinav, and you'll not understand part of the story if you didn't play Chains first.  I finished the game for the second time just now, and I must say, this game is absolutely wonderful.  Wonderful characters, story and voice acting (I played it in English). I loved Sadja and the Staff chemistry, and I think I LOVE the Staff voice actor.  Seriously, I'd listen to him talking forever.   Play. This. Game.

Sadja al-Kedir is magnificent.  Seriously, I really love how it all ties together, and how the resolution throws a different light on everything that has happened.  The characters are varied and diverse, with their own different traits, backgrounds, goals and motivations.   Sadja is a princess, fiercely ambitious and bold, calculating yet terribly reckless - you just really have to play her story to get the full experience of this amazing lady;   Geron is literally an unsung hero, he is underestimated (somewhat justifiably), has a selfish streak and can be dense, but he has his extremely lucky moments of ingenuity and resourcefulness, few though they may be;  Bryda is the perfect mage student, top in all forms and classes, anticipated by senior academics for great things - but she is so very dissatisfied by the current state of magic - obscure, mundane and highly unexciting;   Yet, ultimately, they share a few common themes: desperate determination and loss. And that really shines through, by the end of the story.  Not to mention, it's really super to have characters who have their non-white cultural roots clear to be seen in their personalities and actions, while not falling into roles reflecting exoticism. Characters that stand out from the cast, nonetheless! And are not all-good nor all-evil! Huzzah!!  I really hope there will be more games with such good writing!! I hope daedalic will produce more games featuring characters of Sadja's ilk!!  Please playyyyyyyyy

So my 2nd game of the Dark Eye Universe. You should really play first The Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav.  The sequel gives new hope that i lost after the ending of TDE:CoS bad ending/ outro. So burdensome the first part story ends, so happy i am about this 2nd part. The story has many great parts (ending is better then part 1, but still with a little sad factor), the graphics are still unique and the style work good with all other parts together. The sound is most time plain and appropriate. So you can focus on the main point of the game (riddles, art of design and the tale).  I give this game 92 % for point and click fans. Other people should test it somehow. The price for 7-12 hours is high even for this quality. So wait for a discount and then i hope you enjoy your buy with many funny hours of playing. Thank you for reading.

Pretty solid adventure game, nice graphics, and decent story. Suffers from some illogical puzzle solutions, and one-note puzzle types (item finding/use/combinations) but overall worth playing if you enjoy adventures.

I purchased this game on a whim and it turned out to be amazing. What a fantastic story. I hope there will be another after this one! A few of the puzzles were a tad clunky and there were a few things that just didn't make sense but overall the flow was great. I fell in love with the characters and would absolutely recomend this game. One of the best stories I've seen in a game for quite some time!  My only regret is not playing the Memoria games in order. I guess I'll play the first one second.

I bought this during a sale, so I definitely can't say I was against the price. I was very happy to catch it on sale. What I would say though is that I sincerely wish that it had clearer display towards the top of the store page that told how the game was a Sequal. With the title what it is there's no easy way to tell it is a sequel as there is no number, nor is there a specific statement in the trailer that says it is the sequel. It mentions the first game in the trailer but it lists it as another game the creators made not specifically that it was connected to this one. It definitely is something that is going to have me triple checking games to see if they are the first game or not now.  Aside from this I am genuinely pretty happy about the game. The art, the way the story is told, the music. They all come together beautifully in a way that has me wanting more. I had to look up how many chapters there were within game so to try to keep myself from finishing it too fast. There were several times here and there I was stuck in ways I didn't feel I should have been however. I could tell generally what the overall goal was of what I needed to do even when there wasn't too clear of instruction, but because of how items and surroundings lacked sufficient information I was unable to easily decipher what to link together. Without, as the character would say, 'Random Guess Work.' One place in particular in game was irritating to no bounds for the way one would be constantly reprimanded for making a tiny mistake in a way that made it feel as though there was absolutely nothing one could do. Three characters in the same area, two shouting the third's name so repeatedly that I sincerely think I will never be happy to hear it ever again despite it originally being what I thought was a great name choice.  Overall I'd say it's worth it on sale or not on sale if you like a colorful tale told in a way that makes you feel thoroughly immersed for the way you help to forge the story itself. I would also add despite being disappointed I accidentally played a sequal game before the prequel, this game could be played without the other for how it is an amazing story all on it's own.
Visually stunning, great story and storytelling. A tale I would revisit over and over. A must have for those who love point and click adventures with and amazing story and visuals. Just amazing!

Extremely impressive point and click game that will continue to keep you guessing about what will happen next.   Throughout the game I felt like a detective trying to figure the story out with all its twists. A must play modern point and click that will be engraved in your memories. ;)
kewl and nice art and everything but i don't the part ofi t which is buggin' there f*ckin' much of buggin' in it if it wasn't for that... it would be much greater 'n' awesome.~
I enjoyed the first game in the series ('Chains of Satinav') more, though this sequel was also a great game. The gameplay is very similar to the first. The story is also quite complicated!

This game is awesome... If you're into point-and-click riddle games.  While this isfar from my best type of game, I did really enjoy the story-telling, and the nice plot twist at the end.  So really, if you want a relaxing time with a few good puzzles, you should enjoy this ride.  Memoria is the sequel of another game, but it's not necessary to play it's precursor to understand it. (I started with this game)

Nice, surprising sequel to The Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav.  Sometimes I wasn't sure, if I liked the princess or not. Or the speaking Staff for that matter. But in the end, it was that, exactly, and the beautiful drawn environment that made the game worthwhile.  Handy enough, the user Interface didn't change all too much to it's prequel and this was perfect for me. Besides, the UI disappeared, unless I needed it. Which supports immersion quite nicely.  Tip: As mentioned already a few times, it really adds to immersion and understanding of Memoria, if you played first The Dark Eye.

It isn't obvious from the title, but this is actually a sequel to the Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav, so if you haven't played that, go play it. Otherwise, you might be confused about much of the story, which is never re-explained for new players. That being said, this is an EXCELLENT adventure game, even better than the original in my opinion. Good puzzles, GREAT characters, excellent voice acting, AMAZING story...yeah. Just awesome. It strays from the original in that there are actually two main plots: 1) the framing story, which takes place with Geron and Nuri after the events of the first game and 2) an entirely new story and characters set some 400 years before, during a time of epic war. In many ways, this backstory is actually WAY better than the framing story, although they do come together in the end to make it one cohesive game. They could just as easily have made this flashback its own game set in the same universe. It's that good. I had two glitches while playing, one near the beginning that required a complete restart. It happens if you do things out of the 'intended' order. The other, one of the characters' words switched suddenly to some other language for a line or two. I didn't miss out on anything due to subtitles, but it was jarring.  Overall, a sequel that's as good or better than the original. A fascinating adventure game. 10/10
It's as great as Chains of Satinav. 2D fantasy adventure game are fantastic in my humble opionon. I can't stand for 3rd game form this series!

Recommended. Good point & click adventure game. Nice graphics, good story and, nice puzzles (most of them logical). A nice adventure from Daedelic but, without the humorous seal that often exhibits in their titles.
5/10 Story is interesting, but this game appears to have some bugs and graphic isnt that good. (Game bugged for 2 times, one of them made me have to restart entire game progress)

One of the best fantasy stories I've experienced in video games. It's so awesome I wish it was a graphic novel, and the puzzles actually felt a bit distracting as I just wanted to know what happened to the characters. Not that the puzzles were bad though--not perfect, but pretty solid. I have nothing to complain about.  9/10, -1 only because I'm not comfortable giving perfect ratings.

As a sequel to Chains of Satinav, it does feels like a stronger package. Memoria's art is just as gorgeous, and the voice acting somewhat of a step up. As for the puzzles, some can be quite overly complicated but the unfolding of the story makes it certainly worth pushing on.
Quest + Dark Eye = Perfect

So far, this is the best point-and-click game I've played from Daedalic, and I would rank it amongst the top-tier of point-and-click games. The story is highly engaging with plenty of small unexpected twists throughout - I especially liked the talking staff.

This is a difficult one.  My impresion is that this is a bipolar game. Either that or two teams/people have designed this game independently. At the begining and end of the game, puzzles do not really make sense, whereas there is a period in mid game that this does not happen. This lack of logic leads to an unvelivable amount of frustration. When the puzzles have some logic, the game is frankly quite enjoyable. The story line and the way it is presented and develops through the chapters is nice and inviting.  At the end, the frustration overweights the positive aspects.  I cannot recoment this game.
Part two of 'Chains of Satinav' A very well made point & click adventure game with good puzzles, great voice acting, nice backgrounds and ofc a fantastic story.

Memoria is neither good nor bad. The art and voice acting are adequate. There is nothing that offends me but it has little redeeming qualities. The talking staff is quite fun, though. It's just so bland and unmemorable - pun intended.  I would only recommend it if it's really cheap and if you're bored out of your mind.
previous game in the series was not perfect, this game is worse
Not up to the standards of the first game in the series, not even close. I knew I bought the wrong game when I got to the huge maze section in chapter 3.  Not up to Daedalic's usual high standards.
this game just copied putt putt it doesn't even have a blue car in it

Loved it! An other one of the best puzzle game I've played and don't forget to get the second part (The Dark Eye : Chains of Satinav) it is as good as the first. Good story, fun puzzles, some more chalenging then others. Very fun, I recommand both.  Love that you play multiple characters during the game. You really have to think hard, but it's worth every minute of play time. And I will play them again, because the story is so fun. Also I did the second one before the first, I don't recommand doing that ;) ** Start with Memoria and finish with The Dark Eye : Chains of Satinav.
Great adventure, with great and suprising ending. 80%

Great point and click style adventure game with a well-driven storyline and characters that are hard to walk away from. Reminiscent of the favorite King's Quest style adventure games. The graphics were attractive, but not cutting-edge while the voice acting really pulled me into the characters and was very well done.

This is such a great game. Really magical and mysterious, just the way I like it. Sometimes I got stuck, but there are hints you can get in the game, which is really great. Just a little help on the way when you need it. I love the story and the characters. Somehow I kinda got a crush on the staff... Not sure how that happened.
A really good story telling game .... its worth playing :) ... i liked it
My first play through lasted 5 minutes.  Guy: 'Do you like puzzles?' Me: 'I do not like puzzles.'  *roll credits*  10/10

'As the stone rules over the scarab, so rules the scarab over the stone. Enter if to you the answer is known. If not, then forever your life I'll own.'  Search for the answer to this deceptive riddle in this incredibly well written game by Daedalic Entertainment. Memoria has one of the best narratives in a video game that I have played. The forshadowing and intrigue and absolutely astounding. I love it so much, I would reccomend playing this game even to people if they don't normaly like inventory puzzle games, as long as they love a good Narrative. The only real question is if you play the still good, but less-amazing prequel, Chains of Satinav before you play this one. It is definitely enjoyable without playing it, but it gives away the ending to Chains. Either way, this is definitely the strongest game to come out of Daedalic Entertainment, and one of the best video game narrative in general.

I didn't played The dark eye: chains of satinav,unfortunately,but I just loved this game!! The story hooked me up I was driven the entire game by the desire to know what had happened to Sadja.. I love her and her magic staff! Also I just love the history of the mask and Satinav and the garden,they're just too great!! My only complains are the last 2 puzzles that're way too hard lol The story is really smart and can be difficult to someone to catch at first,but then just google the history of memoria and read the theories. =) If you like adventure games and a good,magical history,then this game is for you! The game art is gorgeous! Excellent voice acting!!

It wasn't a game, it was a story. Once I picked it up, I had a hard time putting it down until I finished playing the game. Daedalic has done a wonderful job of sowing a world together and weaving into it an excellent story.

Okay so I beat the game. Took my 10 hours (because I got stuck a few times. I enjoyed it a lot! Time for a short review.  What's the best thing about the game? Well it would have to be, obviously, the art. All the areas areas to explore are simply gorgeous to look at, and most of it is interactive (main character will at least comment on things you look at).  What's the worst thing about the game? The puzzles are VERY contrived. So many times I got stuck simply because the answer to a puzzle is so difficult to figure out. I had to use a walkthrough after hitting brick walls, but I don't regret it as it allowed me to delve further into the interesting story and awesome visuals.  Example of contrived puzzle : to find a gem, one has to pour wine into a mold, do a service for a mage hidden in a library (seriously, you only see his shadow), find out he can solidify things, then have him solidify the wine. I had no clue that I could use the wine for that. There's also a maze (I HATE MAZES) but THANKFULLY you can skip it after enough time has elapsed (after getting lost). And the end is, to not spoil anything, just strange.  What's okay? The voice acting is well done, ESPECIALLY the talking staff. Music is... forgettable but it fits, controls work very well and the magic spells gives a nice twist to gameplay, though it is underused in my opinion.   Is it worth it? Yeah! Absolutely. If you can forgive yourself for using a walkthrough and just enjoy the story. Seriously, the puzzles are just a headache otherwise. Some parts can be done without one though.  However, I recommend playing the first game first, as it is a direct sequel and many things in this game will be unclear otherwise (why is the fairy turned into a raven?). I didn't play the first game, but I regret it.   Chains of Satinav, get that one first.

An interesting story. I find the setting could have been better fleshed out in the story (e.g. the gods, the battle and so on) but it was, after all, a rather short game. The riddles were interesting and the characters believable. I must say the voice acting in the english version is excellent, as is the art. I'm a bit dissappointed by the ending but I do welcome a non fairy-tale ending, where the hero is perfect in every way.  Overall, a good way to spend some time relaxing and enjoying a beautiful story 8/10.

Bittersweet and interesting story. Some of the puzzles are bit annoying as they require a bit of knowledge from the first game (and I didn' know a first game existed unil I was 3 hours into this one). Still, the characters are likeable and the story is compelling enough to move past the frustration of the puzzles, even for someone who doesn't really like point-and-click puzzle games.

I loved the game, a bit less than the first one (The Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav) though.  If you like classic point and click adventures, with excelent voice acting and artistic develop this game is a MUST have.   The technical problems I had with the first game of the series were gone here... And I'm hoping they will release a new chapter on the series continuing the story about Geron and Nuri. That's the main reason I liked the first chapter more. The story about that couple was the main reason I was waiting to play this title... A bit disappointed about it, because here the main story is about Sadja and her quest and the relationship between Geron and Nuri stays as a secondary story.   For all those you don't know, both games are based on the German Role-Playing Game created by Ulrich Kiesow in 1984, very famous in Germany but not so much in the rest of Europe.
Great game, as his predecessor. Nice ambientation, nice characters
Wonderful game, full of poetry.

This was a good point-and-click adventure, but in my opinion, the prequel, 'The Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav' had a much deeper and more satisfying story to follow. Worth buying and worth the price if you enjoyed the first game, but I'd recommend waiting until it goes on sale.

First of all I can't say enough good things about Daedalic Entertainment. Memoria might be one of my favorite games of all time. This is not to say that every step of the game will take your breath away, but the storyline pulls you into it's world. While I was playing this game I enjoyed it and wanted to keep playing it. After finishing the game? I wanted to play it again. I had to talk myself out of playing it again so soon but I look forward to playing it again once I have forgotten a good bit.   Some users say that you MUST play the prequel before playing this but I disagree. I actually played this first not realizing the two games were connected and playing the prequel second, for me, made both more enjoyable. Whichever order you play them in, this one is just so wonderful.   A must play! Even better if you catch the Daedalic Entertainment: armageddon bundle on sale.
The story is solid. The art is solid. The puzzle style gameplay is challenging but fun.   Be warned, this is a sequel. Play Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav first.

Immersive story.  You play as a Geron, a bird-catcher, trying to restore his girlfriend who's been turned into a raven by a curse and also as Sadja, a princess trying to make a name for herself. Two people, two stories, two different time periods, one awesome epic adventure.   Although this is a game, to me it felt more like an interactive story book. The puzzles we're not that difficult, but not too easy either, which I think is a good thing since it doesn't ruin the pacing of the story. Puzzles make sense, no weird contraptions, no pixel hunting, and it all just fits well in the story.  Absolutely worth it, even if it weren't on sale.  I wish there were a sequel...
This game is not only an amazing point and click with likable characters, but also a work of art. Thes soundtrack is freakin gorg!!

Great story, with beautifull artwork. I really liked the story concept here and thought of it as really clever, it has a lot of a ancient tale one would read to his children. Play it for the story it is worth it, you do not really need to have any knowlege about the black eye or the first game.
8/10 Really Good!  A great and heart-warming story with marvellous character designs and a superb ending! If you are into Point & Click games, then u shouldn´t miss this one ;)

At first the story was not so interesting, but it really got me hooked towards the end. And the end is also good, I liked it very much. The riddles had the right difficulty, sometimes obvious, but more often I really needed some time to figure out what to do.  I recommend it.

I absolutely loved playing this game. The story was very captivating and the characters were well-made. To me it's a real point-and-click masterpiece with its stunningly beautiful artwork. The ending was also really, really good. Definitely recommend playing this game.
Emotionally touching, athmospheric and mesmerizing tale with good voice acting, great music and beautiful art. Highly recommended at reduced price - simply recomended otherwise.
Nice story & interesting characters, i love the theme and I think it's a pretty good point & click adv, though it's obvious it's one of the first daedalic titles
